reviewText:
A bit about the game and developers.
Supreme Commander 2 is a great robotic strategy game developed by Gas Powered Games and published by Square Enix.Gas Powered Games are also developers of Demigod, original Supreme Commander and so on and on, while Square Enix is a publisher of many published games like Tomb Raider, Hitman, Sleeping Dogs and others.

About Gameplay.
Supreme Commander 2 is a strategy game with three different factions. Each faction has its own units. Each Faction has its own bonuses. UEF have strongest unites, most expensive units and units with most HP. Cybran Nation are the weakest but the least expensive. They take the least amount of time to construct and are always largest in numbers. Aeon Illuminate are the most balanced units. Their HP and attack strength fits perfectly with the price of the unit and the construction time. There's one more faction in this game, but since it's unplayable I don't think they are too important.

The game has both single player and multiplayer mode. In single player your objective is, of course, to save the world. The story is pretty good but nothing too special. The awesome thing about this game is the multiplayer. Since the game is about 2-3 years old the servers are very empty. And those that have players are usually professionals and games with them lasts about five to ten minutes. There's tones of strategies you can do to win this game. I played a lot of skirmish games to learn a lot about this game.

To be able to play this game correctly you need to  learn fast. Because even AI is so smart that it can win against you on normal difficulty. It will attack you from all possible directions: water, air and land. It will attack in small waves while slowly building a huge wave of army. The AI is amazing.

It has three different resources. Mass, Energy and Research. You can set up research facilities and energy builders where ever you want, but you can only place Mass on a designed area. Players can fight against each other to be able to own the Mass builders that they need.

You need Mass and Energy to be able to build new units and structures, while you need research points to be able to research for new units, more HP or new building that will help you with who knows what. You need to make sure to always have enough of each, but you also need to make sure that you're able to make a big amount of units since this game is all about large scale wars.

As mentioned before, this game is all about large scale wars.  In my opinion best tactic is to play with two friends. One person focuses on land units, second on water and third on air. That way you can have biggest army numbers due to smallest cost of units. There are two main game types, annihilation and score points. In annihilation your objective is to kill enemy commanders while in score points your objective is to gather as main points as you can by taking over couple of big towers.

Graphic and Audio
Graphic is great! Lasers and rockets everywhere, blown up robots, massive explosions. It's very well made. Details on the units are also extremely nice! Songs are very quiet and calming, but for the most of the time you're so focused on the action and all the lasers that you barely even hear it.

Pros, cons and final grade.
Pros:
- Wonderful graphic.
- Amazingly fun skirmish.
- Huge scale battles.
- Very fun if you have a friend or two to play against the AI.

Cons:
- No players so there are barely any multiplayer games.

Overall grade: 7/10

Extra info: If you're big mech fan as I am, and if you love strategy games, this game is for you. It doesn't involve much thinking, but it's extremely fun to play. Though, don't count on Gundam units to be in this game. Sadly there are no units looking like Gundam ones, hehe.

Thank you![/b]

reviewText:
As a fan of the original Total Annihilation series I liked what the old Cave Dog group did, Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance were good enough, but Sup Com 2 does not do the franchise justice at all. It is a very dumbed down version which replaces many of the original’s mechanics with research grinding rather then building up bases and getting more advanced units. Basic units are just that, basic they are very boring and very small versus the levels and other units, while you can upgrade them with various research items to make them more effective it does a very poor job at replacing the 3+1 unit tier levels from the previous games. With this game now more then ever you rely heavily on the experimental units rather then building up a force of mixed units of various tiers with maybe one or two X units in the mix.

The main campaign does a good enough job at some kind of a story and MOST of the missions are gradual in their difficulty and challenge. However that difficulty spikes abnormally high when you reach the final 4 to 6 missions of the Cybran and you will fail multiple times before you figure out what the developers wanted you to do.

The skirmish AI and the AI in general tends to cheat and does so pretty obviously, getting clear stat, research speed, mass and energy boasts right off the bat, even on normal difficulty, which is a shame because I always enjoyed the TA/SC skirmish games.

I had shied away from buying this game when it came out after hearing reviews that it was a very basic and stripped version designed for mostly console play so I avoided it until 2013’s Christmas sale. I am glad I did because as much as I really wanted enjoy this game and get just as much play out of it as I did with Sup Com/FA and Total Annihilation it would seem that that is not the case. This will be one of the few games that I have purchased that will not last long on my hard drive, possibly to make room for something more worth while.

If you really want to continue to the story of Sup Com and FA, then by all means buy it when it’s on sale again, but do NOT buy this if you were a fan of TA or SC/FA. This honestly makes me worry about what Planetary Annihilation will be like which I hope will not be the case.

reviewText:
Genre - Sci-Fi RTS
I only played this game recently after tying out Planetary Annihilation but finding it too complex for quick games, and I found this game similar in some respects but a lot more accessible. I have played several skirmish games, co-op and 6 missions of the main campaign. You have Land, Naval and Air units to build and research upgrades for. There are three major factions to choose from that are diverse but balanced in most aspects. You need to build up fairly quick and get mixed units to be effective. You fight in a Giant Mech that once destroyed loses you the game. The units are varied enough and the game is enjoyable in quick bursts.
It seems to me to be the natural follow up to Total Annihilation, an old RTS game that received a lot of praise back in my day.  It is the first decent RTS I have played since Starcraft 2.
Don't get me wrong with the comparison at the start though, Planetary Annihilation is also fun but when you are fighting across planets and using orbital platforms it gets very confusing, very fast. However, once you have graduated Supreme Commander 2 school and want more of a challenge, I would try that next. As for me I am happy being a Supreme Commander.

reviewText:
I honestly do not know why this game gets bad reviews as it does from some people. But i absolutely love it. Actually i like it better then Forged Alliance. While Forged Alliance did have some nice bonuses as to putting more then one engineer on a building process and some other things, This game is abit better and more organized in my opinion. In Forged Alliance, to build an Experimental you had to use 1-10 engineers to build it on a random plot of land. In SC2, you can make them from factories.

I for one like that instead of random plots of land. Other things i am sad to see go were the Support Armored Command Units. They were very useful but i wont that ruin my gameplay fun!

The research is a nice add on, limits and makes things more complicated and more advanced. Not to mention very very challenging. Forged alliance was easy once a good base was set up, in SC2, it keeps you active and on alert for a surprise attack.

Another interesting challenge is defending against the Nukes! First time i played it, i was torn apart! But i eventually found a way to defend against 5-6 nukes every 3-5 mins. People also mention units move slow...Actually, they don't. They are 100% the same as Forged Alliance.

Pros:
- Good System of Units
- New Land, Air and Naval Units
- New Structures
- New way to acquire Mass and Energy
- Challenging
- A cool research system that provides complexity
- Keeps you on alert and not underestimating the AI
- Interesting Campaign and Storyline
- Good Multiplayer System
- New and Cool Maps to play on
- Better Graphics
- Better Quality
- Less Laggy then Forged Alliance when building huge hoards of units

Cons:
- Some classic Units from Old games were removed (Not that it is important!)
- Only one engineer per building instead of many that could build one building in Forged Alliance
- No SACUs
- Some Useless Units, but it doesn't affect the gameplay at all
- A little to frequent in Nuke Launching by AI and the # of Nukes is abit to high per strike. (Can be defended if done correctly)

So in conclusion, I would recommend the game to all my friends and surely say, it would be a great purchase and you will have tons of fun and will keep you active for a good time !

reviewText:
In short - a more casual version of SupCom 1. Easier to play, but there's much less to enjoy. Good for casual occasional games with friends. Ultimately, it fails as a Supreme Commander's successor, but stands well as a standalone game.

Although Supreme Commander 1 was meant to be /the/ strategy game, with large maps and huge unit caps, where build orders gave place to thought-out tactics, it ultimately ended up being a base-building simulator, as people grew to refer to it. Supreme Commander 2 trades the large scales for a tighter gameplay, shifting focus from the base to the units.

The units are fewer in variety, each having a distinct role. There is much less fiddling with assembling a perfect mix of the hundreds of different bots, tanks, and airplanes. Choosing your tactics is now more clearly resembling rock-paper-scissors, which is both good and bad, depending on the player.
Also, there are only either big badass mother♥♥♥♥ing guns, or cannon fodder. You don't build a tactical missile launcher to fend off your enemies. It's either a small artillery installation, or a nuke. Same with units vs. experimentals.
But wait, speaking of experimental units, it's not as black and white. As before, they are pretty much useless alone when facing a critical mass of smaller units. Perhaps even more so than in SupCom 1, you will want to provide escorts to your big guys. Here, they are easier to build and to destroy, but having one early enough can still mean a victory.

There is a new resource - Research - gained through battle and boosted by research stations. Tech tiers gave way to global upgrades (purchased with research points) that are applied to all units, buildings, or else - existing and future. This serves to speed up the game, though it takes away from the complexity. Whereas in SupCom 1 destroying an upgraded outpost with tech 3 factories was a big hit, here it doesn't take much to rebuild it. Experiments units are also unlocked with research.
Instead of choosing between spending resources on improving your economy/units and building more units, you just do both simultaneously, while spending any excessive mass/energy you have on research stations.
Speaking of resources, here you don't get to build mass/energy storages - they are unlimited. Instead of draining your money during construction, the cost is deduced at the beginning of the process. Finally, there are no mass fabricators, and I have never seen someone have a problem with energy, for the reactors are very cheap and effective.

There is not much to say of the base. Just as unites, the buildings are also fewer. At the beginning of the game, you are presented with a choice of 8 normal" structures and one "advanced" - the radar. As you research the upgrades for the structures

This game has been one my favorite PC games of all time. Whenever im bored or stressed out I always play SupCom2. I have over 500 hours in the game and going for the magic number 1000

The gameplay is a lot of fun and it requries careful observation of what your doing but also be able to adapt to your opponents strategy. Unlike other strategy games SupCom2 goes fast. Single player is good for begineers to get their hand on all factions and learn basic mechanics of the game. but the story is a little dry. You'll find you will be spending most of your time online or playing skirmish.

Multiplayer is troubling and rewarding. Very few games that you play in Multiplayer will actually be fair games and games are usually less that 30 min. BUT stalemates can last HOURS my longest was 3 hours and the game was so tense. Theres something thrilling about making giant robots shooting each other. The units attack from the land sea and sky. Winning the game isnt that hard either just build the most units as quickly as you can. The hard part is HOW you build those units. Will you build air to counter air? Or anti air units and Bomb Bouncers? Will you push a land force away with magnets or tele to their base.

This game desperatlely needs a community and everyday the player count gets less and less everyday I see the same people online too extremely often when only there are 4 lobbies. But playing the game thrilling and rewarding and was the game that got me into PC gaming. I Love Supreme Commander 2

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Real Time Strategy game with huge maps and tons of units in play. If you liked StarCraft or Command & Conquer, you should enjoy Supreme Commander 2.

The game has 3 separate single player campaigns all taking place approximately the same time regarding an ancient piece of technology that has been discovered. You play a UEF commander (Human), an Illuminate commander (advanced alien race), and a Cybran commander (cybernetic humans) in the intersecting campaigns, all fighting against factions of the other races, as well as the mysterious Cybran Gauge, who seems to know a lot more about the Shiva Prime technology than anyone else.

While the game has similar mechanics to most other Real Time Strategy games, what sets the Supreme Commander series apart is the massive scale of the levels and combat. You have a 300 unit cap and you can really fill the map with units. This is quite a feat because the maps are huge compared to other games like StarCraft or WarCraft. In fact, the maps are so large that you constantly need to zoom out and view the world from a strategic view, otherwise there’s no way you can rely on your minimap to keep an eye on the enemy. Additionally, the research/tech upgrading system is closer to Command & Conquer Generals, where instead of doing your tech upgrades in specific buildings, you access your tech trees in a meta console after you’ve accumulated enough research points. The research points are gained over time from building research buildings or killing enemy units. There are a ton of research options, so you’re unlikely to unlock everything in any given match unless you’re really, really trying.

Pros:
+Decent, long single player campaigns to get your money’s worth out of the game. Just playing single player will probably take about 12 hours to finish. The multiplayer can occupy even more of your time. +I mentioned the extensive tech tree that you can research, and these options can unlock a number of “experimentals” which are basically huge units that can march slowly across the battlefield kicking ♥♥♥. Each race has their own experimentals to use, some better than others.

Cons:
-The graphics aren’t anything special. Dawn of War 2, which came out earlier has more convincing gameplay visuals, though the cinematic cutscenes for both these games aren’t all that impressive.
-The game is really slow in single player. I don’t mean that the game runs slow on my computer, I mean the game is set to be slow paced and you can’t increase game speed (you can adjust speed in multiplayer). This is especially annoying because of how huge the maps are. If you already know you have enough units to win, you’ll probably want to speed up the game as you’re marching towards the enemy with your huge army.


Overall the game is worth a playthrough for the single player campaign, but there are still people playing the multiplayer that you can match with.

reviewText:
The stars of the first Supreme Commander weren’t the massive experimental units, for the most part. There were three tiers of deathbots before you got to those, each five times more massive, devastating and expensive than the last. It was about building dozens of factories, and streaming out enough deathbots to dominate enough of the map to produce enough mass to afford the next tier up. Then: stream out more.

On a 25 square kilometer map, that’s just a very satisfying, physically simulated version of a normal RTS. On a 6,561 square kilometer map, it’s an apocalypse. Your mind goes into overdrive trying to manage eighteen separate assault groups, balance and defend dozens of income sources while ramping up production to meet your snowballing wealth.

But throughout it all, the game takes care of the boring stuff for you: units defend themselves intelligently while moving, they organise themselves in optimal formations and stay in them come hell or high water.

The game has great graphics, but unfortunetly it can't take advantage of our awesome new multi-core CPU's we have today, infact it really only uses 1 core and about 20% of a 2nd if you have it, for example the game ran as fast on my 4.2ghz pentium 4 extreme edition as it did on my Q6600 when I got the game years ago.  Gas Powered games is gone now, but just before they were bought up they released a new AI patch which really helped with a lot of the stupidy the AI had, the AI was already challenging but i quickly found a lot of tactics no longer worked against certain levels of enemies.  Faction balance is terrible in the standard game, imo of course, but once you add the DLC the game gets a whole new persective, every faction can now push there attacks in all 4 major ways (naval, air, land, artillery) except Aion who have no artillery.  At the current price point you would be a fool to not pick up the game and the DLC they are completly worth it.  Single player I still need to finish, I have always been terrible about finishing single player in RTS games though :)  If your playing a large multiplayer match or want to get into multiplayer make sure to get some friends going(you use steam to invite into games), and make sure who ever has the most powerful system hosts the game.

reviewText:
TL;DR: I'll put the tldr segment first because of the way they format the text:
Supreme Commander 2 is a basic RTS that did not hold on to what it had in the first two games of the franchise. If you have not played the first games and are just looking for a nice looking RTS, then this is your game.


I have played Supreme Commander since the original was released back in 2007, I loved that game and it brought many new features to the RTS scene that have now become pretty much standard (ex: “strategic zoom”). After the pretty much utter failure of Forged Alliance, I was pretty surprised to see a sequel to a game whose first installment was pretty good, but had lost grasp on its fans by making a spin off and releasing it as a full game at full price when it really should have been an expansion or DLC. The First two games: Supreme Commander and Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, were both produced by THQ, developed by Gas Powered Games and to quote from the boxes “An Arts From [designed by] Christ Taylor”. These games had many mechanics that separated from other RTSs that were out that the time. The games had a focus on large unit management (I’m talking 1000+ units, none of that 200 max unit stuff you see in other games) to dominate the battlefield, players also had to use the terrain to their advantage to flank their enemies.

The resource management system that was in place in the first titles was also very different from other games at the time. Instead of having a set amount of resource in your position and you’re only able to build units with that set amount (if that makes any sense), SC and SCFA both had a resource rate system. This system would allow you to build as many units as you wanted, just production would slow down if you did not have a high enough rates of resources coming in, creating some pretty interesting situations when you realize that one of you Mass Extractors had been removed and you wonder why you’re not building as fast.

Units in the first two games were handled by a tier system. When you could afford to spend some time and had some extra resource coming in you could choose to upgrade up to two higher (because you start on tier one) tiers unlocking new units and engineers to build. When you obtain enough tier three engineers (for sake of practicality) you could build some pretty power game ender units called Experimental Units. These beasts included things such as a mobile factory that could build almost anything almost instantly and was pretty much indestructible, to gigantic humanoid robots that would shoot laser beams from their eyes. You could also build a unit called a Support Command Units, which were smaller less functional versions of the main Armored Command Units (which is what you play as), pretty much they make great suicidal units.

Now enough about the first to games in the franchise, let’s talk about Supreme Commander 2 (the third game of the series). You may be wondering why I spent all that time talking about the first games in the series; well it’s because they changed all that (well most of it). Publication of Supreme Commander 2 was transferred over to Square Enix, but was still developed by Gas Powered Games. The seconded game had more of a focus on small group combat rather than large scale unit combat like in the first game. The map design was also drastically different with even more of a requirement on terrain use. This wasn’t really a bad thing; the new maps were interesting and helped to balance the support between each kind of unit (land, air, sea). However one of the biggest flaws with in the game was with the units. They scrapped the tier system that was present in the first game for tech tree system. Gone are the days were you could build cheap factories that would pump out meat shields and cheap scouts. With this new tree system the placed in a resource, research points, along with the original two, Mass, and Energy. These points could be farmed or gained just from passing time, and then spent in the tree. Now some of these upgrades are pretty interesting, you can detach the control module of the AUC to make a quick escape and then make a bad-♥♥♥ comeback; but still the heavy focus on the system felt to simplify what made the first games unique and challenging; now all your factories have access two those high power units, and you no longer have to micromanage them. But by far the worst change that they made was to the resource system. They went from an “interest” based income system as I described before, to the standard “bank” system that is present in other RTSs such as Star Craft. This hurt the game, slowing the pacing down from all out action which made the first game amazing fun, to a waiting game to see who can farm the most and get Experimental Units first.

In the end Supreme Commander 2 is a decent strategy game, but that’s all it is. GPG did not stick to what made the first two games so different, high pacing action with ridiculous unit counts and lots of explosions. The maps are interesting enough to keep games exciting for the first few rounds, and the visuals are fantastic even for a three year old game. However I still can’t help but feel hurt that this cult favorite that really was the benchmark for RTSs (both visually and mechanically) at the time it was released has been watered down to please a wider demographic. Also I feel that I should note that it was released a few weeks before Star Craft 2 so that didn’t help with sales. In all I would recommend the first two games over this one: Supreme Commander, and Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, if you want a unique RTS experience and don’t already own them. If you want a beautiful RTS with unique units but really basic mechanics then go right ahead and pick up Supreme Commander 2.

90 out of 100

It's a pretty good game, with several improvements over the original. For one, I definatly like the strategic view where you can organize units into groups. Supreme Commander 2 has a much better campaign and some well-designed skirmish maps. Another key improvement is the differences in the factions. There are a few downsides though. To start there's the desreased unit cap. In the orignal Supreme Commander you could have 1000 units on the field at once, whereas now you can only have 500. Also, some of the units have lost a lot of their original power. Take the fatboy for example, in supreme commander it was an amphibious mobile factory with a shield and immense firepower. Now it's just a large tank.

Overall I'd say buy Supreme Commander first and play for a while, then buy this so you can enjoy the improvemets more and have better understanding of the campaign.

reviewText:
There's a bit of controversy over which of the Supreme Commander games is the best, and the general consensus is that Supreme Commander is a lot more dumbed down and shallow than its predecessor, Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance.

And while I agree with that statement, I had WAAAAY more fun with Supreme Commander 2 than I did with SC1 or SC:FA.

SC2 cuts a lot of the fat out of the previous games and streamlines almost everything.  Just for example, Experimental Units were built directly by builder units in SC1 - in SC2, you can build Experimental Factories and order them to build Experimental Units on repeat.  Similarly, the system of Tier 1, Tier 2, and Tier 3 units has been replaced with a set of core units that can be upgraded via a research tree.

The bad side is that SC2 does have a lower maximum unit cap and generally smaller maps than SC1 and SC:FA.

It'll come down to personal preference, but I think the shift in focus paid off.  SC1 and SC:FA had a lot of depth and required a lot of skill to play successfully, but SC2, though more shallow, is just more enjoyable.

I enthusiastically recommend this game if you're a fan of massive robot battles!

reviewText:
A really fun RTS. The graphics are good but the most noticeable thing about the game are the effects. The flash of weapons firing, targets being hit, things exploding, it all looks really good and this game has some great presentation value. I'm the SUPREME COMMANDER zOMG! A lot of RTS games try to add new things and end up increasing micromanagement big time. I took two micromanagement economics classes in college, I don't need more of it lol. A lot of RTS games just feel like work instead of enjoying a game. This game gives you a way to build armies and to research upgrades and it is not overly detailed with who-cares-what-else. It is easy to get into with a quick and to the point how-to tutorial. Why can't all rts games be this intuitive? Why do they have to add layers upon layers upon layers of micromanagement and boring tedious details? Because the people who make them and play them are pretentious d-bags, that's why. I would play this over pretentious CIV games any ♥♥♥♥ing day.

Although not complicated, it is still a challenge. That's the one problem I've found so far and it sucks: very uneven difficulty spikes. Missions 1-3 out of 5 in the first campaign? Whatever, it was no problem. Mission 4 in the first campaign? It was ♥♥♥♥ing stupidly hard. I got it on my third try when I realized you need to do it a specific way which is one of my biggest pet peeves with games: lack of player freedom. You can't build additional money generators in this mission so you do not have a lot of resources coming in so you have to plan it precisely. I figured out that you have to build a ton of ground/air defense towers and keep engineers repairing them and replacing them as needed. Have enough towers to guard the front and NW/NE sides and a bunch of fighter planes on guard and upgrade their health/dmg fully. Be working up to building the walking juggernaut things as quickly as you can while upgrading ground forces health/dmg fully. Keep pumping out fighter planes from two air factorys. After all this, I sent out two juggernauts with 40 air fighter support planes and blasted everything down finally. God, damn.

I suppose in closing I can say this is a decent RTS game but really it just makes me want to reinstall Starcraft 2.
6.5/10

reviewText:
Supreme Commander 2 (SC2) is much better than Supreme Commander 1 (SC1). Don't believe all the naysayers!

SC1 had tons of different units, 4 tiers and huge maps. The intention behind SC1 apparently was to simulate epic battles. However, it failed at that miserably. The usual multiplayer games didn't last longer than 10 - 20 minutes and ended at tier 1 or tier 2 at most. So you weren't able to use most of the units anyway. No epic battles of several hours (if players played seriously).

SC2 doesn't try to simulate epic battles. SC2 is a very quick game. 1on1 games usually take about 10 minutes. Everything in the game is streamlined for quick games and it never gets boring. The game just makes a lot more sense. Unlike SC1, it doesn't try to be something which it isn't. If you want longer games, play 3vs3 games which can take about 30 minutes.

Cons:

- The online community is practically non-existent. The game is very old after all and most players who play it don't host public games. RTS games in general aren't the most popular games.

Pros:

+ The game isn't expensive. Ask a few friends who like RTS games and play with or against them! IMO, the game is worth its current price of 13€ just for its skirmish mode against AI. There is also a single player campaign for all three factions.
+ There are not tons of different units. Too many units make a RTS too complicated without providing a real benefit. You don't need tons of different units to have a strategic game. Too many types of units just make the game bloated and make it difficult for new players.
+ The size of the maps is just right. No boring wandering around in slow moting in huge maps.
+ The ACU or an engineer can build all buildings. No need to distinguish between T1, T2 and T3 engineers. Better buildings and units are unlocked via the research system. Different tiers of engineers would just have been annoying without providing any strategical depth.
+ Stability. Unlike SC1, SC2 never has crashed on my PC.
+ Easy to pick up, difficult to master. That's what a RTS game should be like. There is a lot of depth in the game, e.g. knowing how to counter which strategy of the enemy.
+ The factions play very differently. Every faction has its own cool things and the balance seems to be very good.
+ Beforehand I was sceptical when I heard that the mass and energy isn't reduced per second when constructing but you have to pay the full amout of mass and energy for buildings and units. In fact it works perfectly. Nothing to miss about the old economy system of SC1 (or Total Annihilation).
+ It is not possible to build a turtle base which withstands everything. Allowing too heavy turtling would only lenghten the game without making it more interesting. In SC2 attacking is the best defense.
+ There is a lot of tension in the game. You always have something to do. There is no time for breaks. Fortunately, a game is short enough to be able to relax *after* the game ;)

Conclusion: SC2 is the result of streamlining SC1. It's not a trivial game like some people may try to make you believe. IMO, the right things were simplified but the developers never oversimplified anything.

reviewText:
The first game was Supreme Commander, then came Supreme Commande : Forged Alliance, then this.

Sadly it doesn't live up to the series.

The whole game feels like a cutdown version of the earlier games, like if someone had to remake Supreme Commander with only a fraction of the budget.

The graphics are worse than the earlier games.  The FMV's are worse quality than the earlier games.

The game balance is poor and air units are overpowered.

The storyline for the singleplayer campaign is weak and very cheesy and every campaign opponent is just a sad predictable spam of gunship formations.

The regular units are bland and experimentals feel more like regular units.

The campaign was easily completable on Hard difficulty for a novice like me, who barely scraped through Forged Alliance on Normal difficulty.

Which leaves only skirmish and multiplayer, where the gameplay is far shallower and blander than the original game and you'll quickly grow bored of it.

What basically ruined this sequel is basically the same thing that ruins a lot of PC game sequels, a studio has initial success and then they set their eyes on the lucrative console market.

Here's a quote from gamespy reviewing the Xbox 360 version of the first Supreme Commander.

Cut out about 50% of the units
date: make the maps smaller and tighten up the bleeding edges to make a new strategic model and we might really have something. The pacing's right
hoursPlayed:
but stuffing the entire PC version of Supreme Commander onto the 360 is just more than the poor machine can handle."

That's pretty much what they did here.

The only thing Supreme Commaner 2 deserves credit for is that on the whole the skirmish A.I is somewhat improved over its predecessors in terms of actually amassing units and launching credible attacks."

reviewText:
As a player of Supcom and Forged Alliance I found Supcom 2 was rather lacking in content, as a point of fact I figured, seeing as it was a continuation of the originals, that jumping into a skirmish rather than learning the controls would be fun, I was wrong. There is no strategy involved, simply throwing masses of troops seems to work fine. The look of the game, both graphically and from my brief inspection of the tutorial, seems very similar to some of Westwoods Command and Conquer games. Were I a new player to the series I'd most likely assume it was a prequel to the originals with the way it looked.

I still had fun though, regardless of my initial shock, and I felt as though it had been made with an older feel in mind.

All in all I was dissapointed with what I got out of this game. Was it good? No. Were it part of a different series of games I may have said differently but this is a poor excuse for a SupCom game.
I do expect I'll play the game more but will no doubt return to the orignal games after completing the  campaign.

Pro's:
Some of the unit names are clear puns which made me chuckle
The old SupCom/FA maps made an appearance
Somewhat corny and old school feel

Con's:
For SupCom players; expect lower graphics than the originals
Seems untempered and in need of tweaks
Lack of strategy value, throw units at the enemy and wear them into the dirt

reviewText:
Think of an RTS as a rhythm game. It's all about finding a decent rhythm in unit production, to research, to micro and macro with your entire army. You must maintain your rhythm while also disrupting your opponent's. I bought this game during the Winter sale for $3.24. This game isn't even worth THAT.

Here's where this game's problem comes in: this game makes no ♥♥♥♥ing sense. The tutorial was written by ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ seven year olds who don't the understand the basic concept of what makes an RTS an RTS. The game's rhythm is all place, it feels like Beethoven did a line of cocaine on his piano and then bashed his face on the piano keys. If my friends have to tell me to not play the Tutorial and just experience the mechanics on their own to like this game, only for me to bash my keyboard in blind fury at the stupidity of the mechanics, things aren't boding well.

This is coming from a person who plays RTS games all the time. I have over 6000 hours on games like Total Annihilation Kingdoms (June 25, 1999), War of the Ring (November 4 2003), StarCraft (March 31, 1998) and StarCraft 2 (July 27, 2010) and WarCraft 3 (July 3, 2002). Mind you, StarCraft 2 came out THE SAME YEAR as this game. It took me FOUR MINUTES to understand the components of StarCraft 1 and how to play it, and even less time to understand StarCraft 2. Each and every one of the games I just spoke of above have superiority in all aspects, leagues above this game. Game feel, mechanics, art design, story, ease of accessibilty, easy to understand, and gameplay. I have not played any of the other Supreme Commander games, but from the looks of it, not only does this game ♥♥♥♥ on its predecessors, but on Strategy games as a whole.

Do not buy this game.

Refunded. I want my ♥♥♥♥ing $3.24 back. No words will be able to express exactly how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ I am on this game. This game caused me to go on a freaking rage rant on the history of Strategy games for around two hours with my friends being forced to smile and nod.

reviewText:
Okay...

My opinion regarding SupCom2 is a little...neutral. The game itself is okay and adds an interesting twist to the SupCom universe. However, it isn't the TRUE successor to the original SupCom game.

For one, the resource system. It just seems...eh. It changed from the positive/negative income and moved to building/unit pricing where you need X amount of resources to buy Y. Doesn't exactly endear me.

Another point is the research tree and research points. Why?! I was perfectly okay with going through three techs. T1, T2, T3. Simple. Easy to understand. But now, I've been given a third resource. I'm a casual gamer, I don't do competitive stuff very often. Rant at me if you wish, but getting a third resource was a pain in the carping ♥♥♥. When I tried to move to focus on one thing, something else suffers. Honestly, I would forget about research and then half way through the match, remember I can upgrade my stuff. So, meh. Not enthused.

I do have a pet peeve. Why can't I order engineers to assist in building something? In SupCom original, build time could be cut down if you assigned an engineer to work on it, of course at the cost of using more resources. But it's gone now. I'm not pleased by the lack of that mechanic, but I can live with it. I guess...
Now, I HAVE to bring up the naming. Seriously, take a moment and look at the Aeon Illuminate unit names. The 'Weedoboth' fighter/bomber? The 'Sooprizer' Experimental Gunship? The 'Fistoosh' Mobile Missile Launcher? I'm mildly amused. And I'm also questioning the alcohol content the designers possessed when they named these. That, or sleep deprivation. Or it could be they had only a week before release. I unno.

One last thing. When I first played SupCom, I was blown away by this 'epic' feeling. The units and their attacks held a kind of weight to them, as if a single shot from a T3 Aeon Battleship could conceivably oneshot most structures and units. Now, these units in SupCom2 just feel dinky and unrefined, even when at maximum upgrade sometimes. Sure, it doesn't hold true to all units, but it's present in most. The build time is also shortened. When you went to build a Tech3 artillery piece on SupCom original, you EARNED it. It took an hour to build that thing, you deserve it and its firepower. In SupCom2, you have TWENTY heavy artys, maybe more. You can spam them for days and don't get me started on the nukes. I'm not even gonna step in that territory of rant. I've done enough for tonight.

Long story short, if you want a sequel to SupCom original, go get Forged Alliance.

reviewText:
Was great, superior to the first game even, until they patched it to play just like the first game (in terms of resource managment) and thus revived all the reasons i stopped playing the original title. Do not recommend.

(EDIT: someone axed a question and steam wont let me type a reply over 1000 characters.)

answer to question about what specifically was changed:

to anyone who hasn't played the original it wouldn't really make any additional sense with context. but 'ere we go!

the original game suffered from a lot of cons: slow down, extremely lengthy build queues, poor balance between factions, the necessity of having pre-created construction blueprints for base building, to name a few. the most poignant of all, however, was the resource management system this RTS employed.

effectively you could queue up ANYTHING regardless of actual resource reserves or resource income rate. buildings, units, upgrades, all of it would simply go into the queue as you picked them. in most RTS games, if you can't afford something, you had to wait until you COULD to produce it. supreme commander 1 said nuts to something easy and efficient such as that!" and decided that to compensate for letting you always be able to construct anything it would merely extend the production time. so now
date: a tier 1 tank that took 20 seconds to create with adequate resources became a tier 1 tank that takes 3 minutes to create as resources trickle in and are equally distributed amongst all queued tasks that you do not pause. this could get GROSSLY out of hand if you were not keeping up with mass and energy generation. experimentals that took 6 minutes to construct were taking 30 minutes. ain't NOBODY but a guy i knew named Andrew had time fo dat.\n\nalong comes supreme commander 2 and SUDDENLY we had a resource management system that made SENSE! (we also had other marked improvements across the board from performance to simplications of unneccessarrilly complicated game mechanics
hoursPlayed: namely the aforementioned Andrew did not enjoy). The system had been changed so that you could queue up whatever you wanted but construction/progess would NOT begin until you had the total necessary resources to complete the item in the default build time. effectively the game was working like every other RTS in existence because you don't revolutionize the wheel by making it into a hexagon.\n\nalong came a patch for SC2 that changed the resource management system into a carbon copy of the system from SC1. this made the game VIRTUALLY unplayable to me. i went from being able to beat the entire game to being unable to launch the game from steam because i couldn't stand that system after having been spoiled by the infinitely superior system the game launched with. the game lost ALL appeal and in an instant became unplayably boring and frustrating. They didn't even make it an OPTION. (did they? i doubt it.)"

Definitely no.

I simply love SC1 (and the expansion). I liked the serious atmosphere, the almost constant battle between resource generation and consumption, the demanding time, resources e careful planning in order to build a decent base with proper defenses. Anyway, SC1 is cool, SC2....eee....no.
SC2 have its merits. The stories and more elaborate dialogues is a good thing but don't save the game. Unfortunately, good RTS games aren't make eith just good stories and dialogues. Everything that make SC1 an awesome game were removed from SC2:

1 - Serious look and atmosphere - SC2 look like some kind of cartoon with bright colors from some kindergarten.

2 - Resources - its easy to get and generate resources. No more paying attention or planning the construction of base or experimental units.

3 - Building base - in SC1 we need to overlap shields (paying attention to energy consumption) and hope they would hold long enought while your defense structures and units take care of the enemey. In SC2, just one shield will do for everything.

4 - Tactics - why bother thinking on how you will get to your enemy? Just spam anything from your factories and make them move straight for the enemy base. Pincer attacks? Too much trouble. Coordinated sea, land and air attack? Even more trouble. Artillery fire? It's boring.

Anyway, the devs maybe were drunk, in a bad mood or just left their kids in charge, i don't know. But they just took everything that make SC1 an remarkable game and throw them in the trash. And painted everything with neon paint....too childish.

3 - Building base - in SC1 we need to overlap shields (paying attention to energy consumption) and hope they would hold long enought while your defense structures and units take care of the enemey. In SC2, just one shield will do for everything.

4 - Tactics - why bother thinking on how you will get to your enemy? Just spam anything from your factories and make them move straight for the enemy base. Pincer attacks? Too much trouble. Coordinated sea, land and air attack? Even more trouble. Artillery fire? It's boring.

Anyway, the devs maybe were drunk, in a bad mood or just left their kids in charge, i don't know. But they just took everything that make SC1 an remarkable game and throw them in the trash. And painted everything with neon paint....too childish.

reviewText:
Supreme Commander 2 is the successor to the critically-acclaimed Supreme Commander 1 and Supreme Commander Forged Alliance titles made by Gas-Powered Games and published by Square Enix.  In the distant future, wars will be fought not by hordes of manned armies but rather swarms of drones remotely commanded by people in giant robots in the battlefield for some reason. This toned down sequel has drawn either much praise or a lot of vitriol from its community.  With such mixed responses, one may wonder if this game is even worth playing, let alone looking at it.  This review hopes to answer that question (summary below):

-Story:  Being a game published by Square Enix, one would expect story to be the primary focus of the game, but it seems that even the story in SupCom2's case was toned down in comparison to its predecessor (even though it was enough for me to want to see what the end looked like).  Throughout the 18 campaign missions divided equally between the United Earth Federation (UEF), Aeon Illuminate and the Cybran Nations, the three factions struggle to keep a fragile alliance together from internal plots to thrust one side into power over all others.  While this may sound dramatic, the tone never gets too grim while also avoiding an overly idealistic view.  The main characters sound like interesting concepts, but they're all executed in an uninteresting way with monotonous speech and limited facial expressions.  It also doesn't help that the FMVs feel lacking and empty.  Despite these facts, the campaigns still provide the benefit of practice for the multiplayer community, at least enough to familiarize the player with each faction.  It's still recommended to practice in skirmish mode and within the multiplayer community itself though.  Whether you care about the story or not, the campaign is at least something to pass the time and learn about the game.  Score:  3/5

-Graphics:  One of the main complaints voiced by fans of the previous Supreme Commander games is that the graphics in SupCom2 aren't nearly as spectacular as its predecessor.  While they aren't as bad as they could be, the presentation of the game is rather simple in a way that's almost lackluster in both unit and world design.  Even on the highest graphical capabilities, the game looks like something made out of legos almost.  The scaling is also a little strange, but it's understandable as to why the developers took this path:  They were betting on the idea that gamers in the start of the 2010's wouldn't be able to afford powerful computers with the best hardware on the market.   As a result, those whom had played the first game and eagerly awaited a new and improved sequel were disappointed while it didn't discourage newcomers from entering the franchise.  If you're the kind of person who doesn't care too much about graphics, this is the game for you.  If you wanted something even more realistic than the first, look elsewhere.  Score:  3.5/5

-Gameplay:  Another complaint by the fans of Supreme Commander 1 and Forged Alliance was that the gameplay was toned down in terms of complexity for SC2.  While Supreme Commander 2 is simpler than its predecessor in terms of strategic depth, this is not necessarily a bad thing.  The goal of the game is to assert your military supremacy with swarms of unmanned units while also avoiding total annihilation.  Units are constructed out of two resources:  Building Mass, and energy which is easier to harness since generators can be placed anywhere as opposed to mass extractors which are placed on strategic points and must be secured.  Instead of tiers, factions can invest research points that are accumulated over time to improve their units on the spot with increased gains in research the more research facilities are constructed.  Rather than requiring buildings dedicated to unlocking research though, one can just simply access their tech tree and spend points on what they can afford.  While this does sound better than the typical method of improving units, it can be tedious or outright absurd to feel the need to relearn upgrades every single game.  SupCom2 also benefits from allowing players to plan joint-operations with their land, naval and air units and the sheer size of one's armies, fleets and squadrons is still impressive with support up to as many as 500 units per team.  While some may complain about the downgrades given to each faction's late-game experimental units, they are still powerful enough to require planning to deal with effectively.  The view of the game is also impressive since not only is there a typical minimap with fog of war that's already drawn, players can zoom out and view the entire battlefield to coordinate multiple assaults in real time.  It may seem overwhelming at first, but it won't be take long to improve one's micro-management and multi-tasking skills.  To put it simply, if you're looking for a game with strategic-depth that's important for a long-term goal, play SupCom 1.  If you are more a fan for smaller-scale battles of tactics, SupCom 2 is the game for you.  Score:  4.5/5

-Sound:  Even though it seems that sound wasn't a high-priority for Supreme Commander 2, there's still a small OST that might have been complimented if it only had more songs and influences from the kind of music heard in games like Hawken or Battletech.  There is a recurring leitmotif here that may be detected on and off, but is rather downplayed in contrast to everything else.  Fittingly, there is dynamic music in Supreme Commander 2 that shifts to match the intensity of the battle with almost nothing but wind at the start and a building orchestra that climaxes once the battles rage.  The warnings for this game only tells you of critical information that requires immediate attention such as “Nuclear launch detected” or “Commander under attack”.  The voice acting for the game feels mostly restrained, with lines alternating between hit-and-miss sarcastic remarks and attempts to add character development that fall flat most of the time.   Not much to say here, but it probably could have used something more.  Score:  3/5

-Replayability:  Despite the divided fanbase in regards to Supreme Commander 2 and its predecessor, SC2 still has hundreds of players in the multiplayer community.  The community hub is still fairly active, and there is a modding community for the game as well, just like the first game.  Even if you're not into multiplayer, Supreme Commander 2 has a campaign that would probably last the average player about a week or a week and a half to complete just for the regular objectives alone.  For completionists, there are also hidden objectives to discover in each campaign mission to improve one's score.  There is also skirmish mode which can be played against AI with misleading difficulty values.  Fortunately the game's AI opponents are relentless enough even on Normal to improve one's strategy and drive them to feel accomplished as they eventually defeat their opponents.  The good news is that this game will last a good while for fans of short-term RTS games.  Average life expectancy would probably be around a month just for the singleplayer alone and several for multiplayer if it still lives on.  Considering that the story ending on a cliffhanger that probably won't be answered any time soon, if at all, SC2 is in no danger of being replaced by a sequel unless a spiritual successor is developed.  Score:  4/5

-Summary:  Supreme Commander 2 is the kind of game that's enjoyable in its own merits. If it weren't so conflicting with the lore, it's probably be more tolerable to SupCom 1 fans if SC2 could be thought of as a prequel in disguise as a sequel. If you aren't too judgmental about graphics or complexity and just wish to have a fun, futuristic short-term RTS, then Supreme Commander 2 is for you.  Overall Score:  18/25 or 72%.
